awd_titl_txt: Multistationarity and Oscillations in Biochemical Reaction Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on two of the most important behaviors in biological dynamics, playing key roles at all scales, from molecular to cellular, to tissues and organisms.  Multistationarity refers to the capacity of a system to operate at alternative steady-states, and is observed experimentally as irreversible switch-like behavior; oscillatons are periodic variations in the  concentration of interacting elements (genes, metabolites, enzymes, etc).  The interplay of multistationary and oscillatory behavior underlies crucial physiological processes: cellular division, differentiation and apoptosis, cellular signaling, enzyme regulation, circadian rhythms, and membrane potential activity in neurons and heart cells are only a few examples.  Many diseases involve disturbances of these processes as a result of deregulation of multistationary and oscillatory behaviors in specific gene networks or biological pathways.  A better understanding of the two behaviors may lead to developments in the study of such diseases.  In this project, the investigator will create mathematical tools and software that will allow biochemical and biomedical scientists to analyze dynamical features of relevant biological systems. 

The emergence of multistationarity and oscillation is intimately linked to the existence of feedbacks and to other subtle features of the structure (i.e. wiring diagram) in the underlying reaction network of interacting elements.  Design principles associated to multistationarity and oscillations have long been proposed and refined over the years, but there is not yet a complete picture of the relationship between structure on one hand and multistationary or oscillatory behavior on the other.  In this project, the investigator develops new mathematical theory and expand existing results to strengthen our understanding of this connection.  In particular, algorithms will be developed to identify key structural properties of biochemical reaction networks that give rise to multistationarity and oscillation.  These developments will be implemented in user friendly, open source software, to assist and complement theoretical and experimental work in biochemical and biomedical fields.  For example, in a joint effort with experimental collaborators, the investigator will analyze the ERBB network of receptor tyrosine kinases whose multistable behavior is involved in early events in cancer onset.  This work also opens up exciting possibilities in bioengineering for the design of reaction networks with prescribed properties, relevant to research in cellular differentiation and with applications to tissue engineering and drug development.

por.por_cntn:
Our project led to a number of significant advances, particularly in the area of multistationarity of reaction networks. Multistationarity, or the existence of multiple positive  steady states is central to key biological processes, like cell division, differentiation, or apoptosis.  

The general question of existence of multiple positive steady states in biochemical reaction networks often boils down to the notoriously difficult study of real solutions to high-dimensional algebraic systems. As an alternative, much of the research in multistationarity has focused on devising necessary conditions for the existence of positive multiple steady states by studying the injectivity of the corresponding vector field. Injective vector fields cannot yield multistationarity, but non-injective vector fields are not automatically multistationary.       

One of the main outcomes of our project is a complete characterization of injective reaction networks for mass-action, power-law, and general kinetics. Our work completes the study of injective networks, and also sets up a matrix-theoretical framework for attacking remaining questions on the relationship between injectivity and multistationarity.  

A second major outcome of the project deals with sufficient conditions for multistationarity. Specifically, we have studied how multistationarity is inherited in reaction networks from its subnetworks. We have identified a number of modifications (like adding new reactions, or adding new intermediates in certain ways) where multistationarity persists as we build up a network. We have shown that some of these modifications also preserve the capacity of the network to undergo Hopf bifurcations, and oscillatory behavior. This work is an important step towards a rigorous theory of network motifs, namely simple, frequently occurring structures from which some properties of the system may be inferred. 

The project has also contributed to the development of CoNtRol, an open source, user friendly webserver that performs computations for reaction networks, and to the development of an informational wiki resource on the mathematics of reaction networks. A number of undergraduate students were involved in the project. They received training in reaction networks, and  have contributed coding work to CoNtRol, or co-authored research manuscripts. Three of these undergraduate students have accepted programming/data analysis positions in industry, and five others are pursuing graduate studies in mathematics, chemistry, and biochemical engineering. The project has helped fund a doctoral student (PhD 2018), and has opened research avenues explored by two current PhD students. Moreover, the project facilitated a number of synergistic activities at West Virginia University, including a yearly competition for undergraduate students, a weekly math club for high school students, and the introduction of two new courses in mathematical biology and dynamical systems.
